node.title: Is the Problem Facebook? Or the Internet?
node.description: Tech reporter Casey Newton takes us inside the Facebook Papers consortium, the companyâ€™s failure to be held to account and why the problem is bigger than any one company.
node.content: ["The Facebook Papers and whistle-blower testimony have given us yet more insight into the company\u2019s impact on polarization and mental health, but if you could wave a magic wand and \u201cpull the plug on Facebook,\u201d would these problems go away? Casey Newton, the journalist behind the newsletter Platformer, says no. Imagining a universe where \u201cMark Zuckerberg is not the C.E.O., the company doesn\u2019t exist \u2014 I actually don\u2019t think you would improve the internet that much,\u201d he says. He caveats that Facebook has never been held accountable \u201cin any meaningful way,\u201d but the problems are much bigger than any one platform.", "This may make him a Facebook \u201capologist\u201d in the eyes of Kara Swisher \u2014 which is exactly why she invited Newton onto the show to discuss everything Facebook.", "[You can listen to this episode of \u201cSway\u201d on Apple, Spotify, Google or wherever you get your podcasts.]", "In this conversation, Newton and Swisher discuss Facebook\u2019s rebrand to Meta and debate the merits of the metaverse. They go inside the Facebook Papers consortium looking into the whistle-blower leaks, discuss whether the company\u2019s recent limits on facial recognition signals a shift in Mark Zuckerberg and talk about the role of government to really start regulating a behemoth company and industry.", "This episode contains strong language.", "(A full transcript of the episode will be available midday on the Times website.)"]
